subject: [Read_Alphabet] Netiquette was: Schwa/wedge merger in QS
msgSnippet: Please don t bottom-post. Having to scan my way down past something I ve already read, in order to find out if there s anything new, is a tedious waste of
messageBody:
Please don't bottom-post. Having to scan my way down past something I've already read, in order to find out if there's anything new, is a tedious waste of time.

   But by anything you might want to believe in, by all means don't anyone intersperse posts.

From: Benct Philip Jonsson <bpj@...>
To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Sat, November 14, 2009 10:47:05 AM
Subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Schwa/wedge merger in QS

Warren skrev:
>
>
> --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "Charles Smith"
> <Roasted_Beanie@...> wrote:
>> I've been wondering about this for a while, and I want
>> everyone's opinion.  What do you think of the fact that schwa
>> /@/ and wedge /V/ share a letter in QS?  Do you agree or
>> disagree with this merger? Shavian had separate letters for
>> these sounds, which is the way I think it should be. (Also,
>> as a consequence of this merger in QS, the sounds 3` and @`
>> [as well as @r, as in "array"] share the same sequence.)  Has
>>  anyone thought to propose an extra letter to make the
>> distinction? Perhaps one could separate the
two versions of
>> #36 to make the distinction.
>>
>> This isn't to say, however, that I don't like QS, because I
>> do; I've been using it since the early 2000s (on and off
>> admittedly).  If QS were ever to be considered to replace the
>> Latin alphabet, I'd be wholeheartedly in favor of it.  This
>> is just one of the few issues I have with QS.
>>
>  > I believe they should have been retained for those that hear
> and speak these differently.  I believe that he removed them
> over a concern that most people could not spontaneously produce
> the correct spelling -- but I don't thing that is a valid
> concern.  As long as the rules make sense, you'll remember the
> canonical spelling if you are exposed to it enough times.  If
> you don't hear or speak the differences then it's fine to
> change the
spellings for your own use.
>
> I think a more important question is how do you determine whose
> local canonical spelling becomes the international standard.
> Or would you have different dictionaries for Canada, US, UK,
> Australia, and Jamaica?  As a western Canadian I don't hear or
> speak the difference between the two and I merge other sounds
> as well in daily speech.  I don't think it would be a problem
> for people to learn the canonical spellings of words even
> though they don't hear or speak them that way.

Please, don't top-post!

I think another concern was to get enough suitable symbols.
Given the principles of symbol formation Read had choosen
for QS -- wanting to get rid of the more hard-written shapes
of Shavian like EAT, AGE, ICE, UP, OUT, OIL -- he could only
tease out so many usable vowel signs, so he sacrificed that
distinction which carried the least functional load.

/BP 8^)>
--
Benct Philip Jonsson -- melroch atte melroch dotte se
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
  "C'est en vain que nos Josués littéraires crient
  à la langue de s'arrêter; les langues ni le soleil
  ne s'arrêtent plus. Le jour où elles se *fixent*,
  c'est qu'elles meurent."          (Victor Hugo)
